last_episode_to_air.name: Little Richard: King and Queen of Rock 'n' Roll
last_episode_to_air.overview: Featuring interviews and exclusive archive footage, this documentary tells the extraordinary story of a music icon: the self-proclaimed architect of rock 'n' roll

name: Arena
overview: Arena is a British television documentary series, made and broadcast by the BBC. Voted by leading TV executives in Broadcast as one of the top 50 most influential programmes of all time, it has run since 1 October 1975 with over five hundred episodes made, directed by the likes of Martin Scorsese, Alan Yentob, Roly Keating, Frederick Baker, Volker Schlondorff and Vikram Jayanti. Arena's subjects are a roll-call of the world's best known cultural figures from the 20th and 21st centuries, from singers Bob Dylan and Amy Winehouse to academics Edward Said and Eric Hobsbawm, from writers Jean Genet and V S Naipaul to artists Francis Bacon and Louise Bourgeois. The current series editor is Anthony Wall.

episodes.name: Theatre
episodes.overview: Premiere. Ronald Eyre reviews what's going on in the theatre, Kenneth Tynan talks to Laurence Olivier about Lilian Baylis and The Old Vic, and a film about David Hockney's sets for The Rake's Progress.

episodes.name: Art and Design
episodes.overview: George Melly looks at how they sold the 70's and a report on the opening of the Space Studios.

episodes.name: Theatre
episodes.overview: An interview with Howard Barker, author of 'Stripwell', and an extract from same; commentary by Kenneth Tynan; and an investigation of 'Birds of Paradise'.

episodes.name: Art and Design
episodes.overview: Cartoonist Mel Caiman on the New Yorker magazine and its artists, Richard Hamilton at the Serpentine Gallery, and a new documentary exhibition from Jarrow.

episodes.name: Theatre
episodes.overview: Peter Hall talks about the history and new South Band location of the National Theater, where he is artistic director.

episodes.name: Art and Design
episodes.overview: Features Observer critic William Feaver on Painting the End of the World, Bill Brandt's selection of landscape photography at the Victoria and Albert Museum, and the best of science fiction illustration.

episodes.name: Theatre
episodes.overview: Extract from a contemporary play and Kenneth Tynan opines.

episodes.name: Art and Design
episodes.overview: Shirley Conran is the guest columnist; fashion photographer Barry Lategan is filmed working; and Victorian painter Edward Burne-Jones' London exhibition.

episodes.name: Theatre
episodes.overview: Deborah Norton reviews British stage events, a play extract, and Kenneth Tynan opines about the theatre.

episodes.name: Art and Design
episodes.overview: Guest columnist Terry Measham; a look into the work of painter and poet Charles Tomlinson.

episodes.name: Theatre
episodes.overview: Mikhail Baryshnikov and Natalia Makarova rehearse for a BBC New Year Gala Performance; Kenneth Tynan draws a portrait of Albert Finney.

episodes.name: Art and Design
episodes.overview: Filmmaker Roger Graef and journalist Simon Jenkins discuss the destruction of historical buildings, in light of a recent SAVE campaign report and the conclusion of the European Architectural Heritage Year.

episodes.name: Theatre
episodes.overview: Deborah Norton returns with reports, interviews and extracts from what is liveliest and best in the British theatrical scene.

episodes.name: Theatre
episodes.overview: Jonathan Miller introduces this week's look at what is most stimulating and enjoyable on the theatrical scene.

episodes.name: Art and Design
episodes.overview: A look at American photographer Paul Strand and recent trends in British photography.

episodes.name: Theatre
episodes.overview: Arena goes to Scarborough for the British premiere of a new Alan Ayckbourn play "Just Between Ourselves".

episodes.name: Art and Design
episodes.overview: Arena looks at aspects of community art and the work of painter Keith Grant, artist-in-residence at the New Charing Cross Hospital.

episodes.name: Theatre
episodes.overview: Claire Bloom and Kenneth Tynan discuss extracts from Samuel Beckett's 'Happy Days', George Bernard Shaw's 'Too True to be Good', and Tennessee Williams' 'Sweet Bird of Youth'.

episodes.name: Art and Design
episodes.overview: Arena talks with Robert Janz and Dante Leonelli about incorporating time into sculpture.

episodes.name: Theatre
episodes.overview: Arena brings extracts from Paris' contemporary theatre season, including Frank Wedekind's 'Lulu' and Marguerite Duras' 'Days in the Tree', and an interview with Delphine Seyrig.

episodes.name: Art and Design
episodes.overview: Arena presents the work of British and American video artists.

episodes.name: Theatre
episodes.overview: Barbara Jefford, Laurence Olivier, Joan Plowright, Kenneth Tynan Billie Whitelaw and many of the people behind the scenes say goodbye to the Old Vic building.

episodes.name: Art and Design
episodes.overview: Liverpool poet and painter Adrian Henry visits 'The Face of Merseyside'; Boyd and Evans use photographs as the basis of their explorations of everyday life.

episodes.name: Theatre: Happy Birthday Royal Court
episodes.overview: Alumni of the Royal Court celebrate its 20th anniversary.

episodes.name: Art and Design: Art for Money's Sake?
episodes.overview: Barrie Penrose investigates a multi-national art empire and the artists and methods that created it.

episodes.name: Edinburgh International Festival 1976: Part 1
episodes.overview: Features Elisabeth Schwarzkopf, Galina Visnevskaya in the Scottish Opera's production of Macbeth, The Kantor Theatre Company from Poland, and Fenella Fielding in a late-night revue.

episodes.name: Edinburgh International Festival 1976: Part 2
episodes.overview: Features the La Mama Theatre Company from New York; Bunraku, traditional Japanese Puppet Theatre; a recital by Frederica Von Stade; and Judith Blegen as Susanna in 'The Marriage of Figaro'.

episodes.name: Edinburgh International Festival 1976: Part 3
episodes.overview: Writer Germaine Greer and her god-daughter Ruby take a look at a child's Edinburgh Festival and some of the fringe activities, including Gruppo Teatro Libero from Rome and Quentin Crisp.

episodes.name: Theatre: A Dream Come True
episodes.overview: A look at the opening of the Royal Exchange Theatre in Manchester.

episodes.name: Robert Altman
episodes.overview: Gavin Miller interviews the director Robert Altman on "M*A*S*H", "Nashville", "Buffalo Bill and the Indians" and more.

episodes.name: Art and Design: After Samuel Palmer
episodes.overview: David Gould, the expert who discovered Tom Keating's Samuel Palmer imitations, shows the process of identifying and analyzing suspected pictures.

episodes.name: Frank Westmore
episodes.overview: Gavin Millar talks with Frank Westmore, whose family has dominated the make-up departments of American cinema for decades.

episodes.name: Theatre
episodes.overview: Peter Shaffer, writer of 'Equus', talks about his plays, his life and the theatre with an excerpt from the 1976 stage production of 'Equus'.

episodes.name: Cinema: Eric Rohmer
episodes.overview: Gavin Millar interviews director Eric Rohmer about 'Die Marquise von O', 'Claire's Knee' and 'Love in the Afternoon'.

episodes.name: Art and Design: The Illustrators: The Work of Mick Brownfield and Allan Manham/The Swish of the Curtain
episodes.overview: British illustrators Mick Brownfield and Allan Manham are documented working on their current projects; Artist Chris Orr probes the dreadful truth behind the net curtains of suburbia.

episodes.name: Don Siegel
episodes.overview: Don Siegel, director of 'The Shootist', 'Charley Varrick', 'Coogan's Bluff', 'Dirty Harry' and many other violent thrillers talks about the problems of the director who is typecast by his success in one specialized genre.

episodes.name: Theatre: The Cultural Common Market
episodes.overview: A look at Theatre National Populaire, one of France's leading theaters, and Patrice Chéreau's 'La Dispute' by Marivaux and Roger Planchon's 'Tartuffe', as well as scene's from Planchon's scenes from his Blues, Whites and Reds.

episodes.name: Cinema
episodes.overview: In light of the low proportion of British films in the 20th London Film Festival, Gavin Millar looks at what's wrong with the British film industry and distribution system.

episodes.name: Art and Design: Sculpture for the Blind/Linda Benedict-Jones/James Boswell
episodes.overview: Sculpture for the Blind - a special Tate Gallery exhibition; Linda Benedict-Jones, photographer; James Boswell - a revival of his war pictures.

episodes.name: Cinema
episodes.overview: Arena speaks with Spanish directors at the Madrid premiere of 'The Long Vacation of 36'.

episodes.name: Theatre: Brecht in Newcastle
episodes.overview: 20th anniversary tribute to Bertolt Brecht at Newcastle's University Theatre with scenes from 'The Good Woman of Setzuan' and prose, poetry and music.

episodes.name: Cinema: Christmas Special
episodes.overview: A look at the Disney exhibit at the Victoria and Albert Museum; an interview with 'The Ritz' director Dick Lester and actress Rita Moreno; an excerpt from Buster Keaton's 'Spite Marriage'; and the results of the Titles Competition.

episodes.name: Cinema
episodes.overview: Gavin Millar talks to Mel Brooks just before the London release of 'Silent Movie'.

episodes.name: Art and Design: Sam Smith: Genuine England/Arena Review
episodes.overview: An introduction to the magical world of wood-sculptor Sam Smith, plus a look at one of this month's major exhibitions.

episodes.name: Cinema
episodes.overview: Gavin Miller talks to director Martin Ritt, writer Walter Bernstein, and actors Woody Allen and Zero Mostel about 'The Front'

episodes.name: Theatre: Spokesong/At Home with Mole
episodes.overview: An interview with Stewart Parker about his new musical 'Spokesong' with excerpt; a profile of 81 year old actor Richard Goolden with scenes from 'Toad of Toad Hall' and Tom Stoppard's 'Dirty Linen and New-Found-Land'.

episodes.name: Art and Design: Ralph Steadman
episodes.overview: Ralph Steadman illustrates a children's anti-war story, caricatures at his local pub, and speaks about his drawing techniques and his work, including Alice, and impressions of the Patty Hearst trial and the Watergate hearings.

episodes.name: Cinema
episodes.overview: Gavin Miller discusses 'Network' with director Sidney Lumet and Robert Kee; Alberto Cavalcanti talks about his film career on the occasion of his 80th birthday.

episodes.name: Theatre: The Cultural Common Market: Peter Stein and the Schaubuhne
episodes.overview: Peter Stein, director of Die Schaubuhne theatre co-operative, comes to London with his Shakespeare Project. Includes extracts from 'Summerfolk' and 'Shakespeare's Memory'.

episodes.name: Cinema
episodes.overview: Gavin Millar talks to New Yorker critic Pauline Kael about Costa-Gavras' 'Z' and 'Section Speciale', along with her passion for the movies and how she wields her power.

episodes.name: Art and Design: What Is a Hologram?/Kit Williams - Ring Around the Moon
episodes.overview: Arena investigates holograms and their potential in the arts; artist Kit Williams' vivid folklore paintings.

episodes.name: Cinema
episodes.overview: On the occasion of the release of the third film version of 'A Star is Born', James Mason talks about the curious business of stardom and how it has changed.

episodes.name: Theatre: A Night Out
episodes.overview: Arena visits three theatres - the Mercury Theater in Colchester, the Humberside Theatre in Hull, and the Duke's Playhouse in Lancaster - to find out what they are doing, how they are doing it and why they think they should go on doing it.

episodes.name: Cinema
episodes.overview: A look at Ealing Studios, including excerpts of many of their popular films.

episodes.name: Art and Design: Family Pieces/Both Sides of the Line/The Divine and the Fantastic
episodes.overview: Portrait painter Philip Sutton; Helmut Weissenborn, a German WWI soldier who illustrated with wood engravings the war diary of Edward Thomas, an English poet who died in WWI; and Gothic art in Cologne.

episodes.name: Cinema
episodes.overview: In a special edition from Rome, Gavin Millar interviews Bernardo Bertolucci, director of 'Last Tango in Paris' and '1900', and Gore Vidal on Hollywood and 'Cinecitta'.

episodes.name: Theatre: The Prospect Before Us
episodes.overview: Prospect Theatre Company reopens the Old Vic. Includes rehearsal footage from 'St Joan', 'Hamlet', 'Antony and Cleopatra', and 'War Music', a new musical adaptation of 'The Iliad' by Christopher Logue.

episodes.name: Cinema
episodes.overview: Gavin Millar talks to director Bernardo Berolucci in Rome about '1900', his new five and a half hour film, as well as his earlier work.

episodes.name: Art and Design: The Continuous Diary/Dine's Drawings
episodes.overview: The artist Ian Breakwall gave up painting for the art of a daily diary; Jim Dine explains why he returned from pop art to drawing the human figure.

episodes.name: Cinema
episodes.overview: Arena looks at erotic films, including 'Je T'Aime Moi Non Plus', 'Hardcore', and 'Come Play With Me'.

episodes.name: Cinema
episodes.overview: An interview with Sophia Loren on the occasion of the opening of 'The Cassandra Crossing'.

episodes.name: Cinema
episodes.overview: Mr Universe, the Crazy Horse Girls de Paris, Yum Yum Shaw, superstars with police escorts, topless bathing beauties-the Cannes Film Festival still sometimes seems more like a circus than a trade fair. But for all that, film people find it an indispensable fortnight in their calendar. More buying, selling and setting up of movies takes place in the jostling corridors of the Carlton Hotel in the last two weeks of May than anywhere else the rest of the year. A report on the business and the ballyhoo.

episodes.name: Theatre: Playwrights of the 70's
episodes.overview: In the last ten years an astonishing number of new writers have emerged. Plays by Barrie Keeffe, John McGrath, David Hare, Howard Barker, Howard Brenton, Trevor Griffiths and Stephen Poli akoff have been performed at the Royal Court, the Aldwych, in the West End and at the National  Theatre. The plays they write are about violence, sex and politics. How accurate and useful is their portrayal of society? What is the reason for their success? What are their own roots, influences and attitudes?  In an extended Arena, writer and critic Albert Hunt assesses this renaissance of British playwrights, which has given the theatre of the 70s a distinctive voice.  Including interviews with, and extracts of plays by: Howard Bren ton, Trevor Griffiths, David Hare, Barrie Keeffe and John McGrath.

episodes.name: Edinburgh Festival
episodes.overview: Features the 1977 Edinburgh International Festival with a new production of Carmen, the experimental shows, Film Festival, Television Festival, and art galleries.

episodes.name: Cinema
episodes.overview: with Gavin Millar returns for a new season after a visit to Hollywood, which despite rumours of slump and panic is still the unquestioned capital of the cinema world. We talked to one of its ruling princes, John Franken heimer, director of The Manchurian Candidate and Grand Prix, about his career in the Dream Factory, and especially his latest suspense thriller Black Sunday.

episodes.name: Cinema
episodes.overview: Diane Keaton and Woody Allen talk about the filming of 'Annie Hall' and their long friendship.

episodes.name: Theatre: Hands Off the Classics
episodes.overview: In the 17th century Troilus and Cressida was censored and in the 18th century Tate gave King Lear a happy ending. The programme debates the line between interpretation and vandalism.

episodes.name: Art and Design: The Family/Wrapping up the Reichstag
Cinema: The Force is with us?
Art and Design: 'The Journey' or The Memoirs of a Self-Confessed Surrealist
episodes.overview: George Melly explores his lifelong relationship with surrealism in all its forms and prominent personalities; Henry Moore discusses Leonardo da Vinci's anatomical drawings.

episodes.name: Cinema: The Force is with us? - Part 2/Howard Hawks
Theatre: ' But please, this is a farce! ' The story of The Cherry Orchard
Theatre: Hey Kids! Let's Do the Show Right Here ...
Close Encounters of the Third Kind
Art and Design: Way Out West
Television: When Is A Play Not A Play?
episodes.overview: A tribute to the British filmmaker Alan Clarke (1935-1990).

episodes.name: Frank Sinatra: The Voice of the Century
episodes.overview: Arena explores the rise of the legendary crooner Frank Sinatra from his early family background to overwhelming showbusiness success. Interviews with friends, family and associates reveal a star-studded career in music and film.

episodes.name: Screen Goddesses
episodes.overview: Documentary about the early female movie stars: Greta Garbo, Marlene Dietrich, Rita Hayworth, Marilyn Monroe - immortal goddesses made by Hollywood to reign over the silver screen.

episodes.name: Bergman: A Year in the Life
episodes.overview: Documentary that exposes a darker, less well-known side of film director Ingmar Bergman, focusing on the landmark year of 1957, which saw Bergman direct two films and four plays.
